comments.commentBody:
Trump's populism is not dependent upon economics, economic class, or policy positions.

This election demonstrated that the Republican base is indifferent to sexual scandals, financial chicanery, and overt expressions of racism by their candidates. Forget about the shallow pretensions of the 'Moral Majority' of yesteryear - Trump has demolished the last remnants of that facade.

The Republican base voted for an Attitude, with little expectation of any actual results from their candidate. Rhetoric is more important than results. That attitude is a snarling, free-floating cynicism that borders on outright nihilism that has become the core of their identity as Americans.

The Confederacy thrives on rejecting the Union, or the 'establishment' in today's terminology. The Civil War continues, and to no good or meaningful end.
Sound familiar ......reconstruction 1865.

We will all become the social-engineering playthings of a few plutocrats, just like all these thousands of poor students in Detroit, whose lives were destroyed by Betsy DeVos's disastrous charter school experimentations.

But let's look at the bright side: it will all make for darling cocktail chatter, as Betsy and her ilk gather to think about how to experiment next with the little people, reveling in the vainglorious certainty that obscene inherited wealth produces valuable ideas and useful expertise in addressing complex public policy issues.
How much damage can one family inflict -- with her brother head of Blackwater!

"With Trump the plutocracy has taken over Washington"

Hillary was not plutocracy? What was Trump running against, Bernie? It was the plutocratic status quo that has looted this country for themselves, and all their wars and twisted economics.

In most places across this whole country, enough people disliked Hillary so much they'd vote for even Trump just to reject her.

R. Law & gemli:

I may slip occasionally, but I have begun to lower-case his name. To maintain respect for the office, come January 20 it will be President trump.

Why is anyone surprised?

He said he was gonna hire "experts" - he just didn't say "experts in getting money."

From the Amway DeVos clan (MLM scheme) to the Crisis Consultants (Rudy profiting off 9/11) to the extractive energy despoilers...

they've all gotten rich from other people's sweat, other people's tears, other people's land and water.

Why is anyone surprised that a huckster prefers the company of hucksters?

What the GOP has learned over the past decade is that compromise is not rewarded by voters or the media. Instead, being a true opposition party that sets its own agenda and fights every step of the way is the path to victory.

It is time for the Democrats in the Senate and elsewhere to learn that lesson and flip the script on the GOP. Do not enable, normalize, or compromise with the phony populist con man who lost the popular vote by more than 2 million votes yet will be our next President, and do not compromise with or enable the Koch Brothers' GOP lackeys in the Senate and House. Instead, Democrats must set forth their own populist progressive economic agenda, and fight the coming Republican efforts to privatize Medicare and Social Security, destroy ObamaCare and public education, and line the pockets of billionaires. If Trump or other Republicans want to come across the aisle and support part of our agenda, great. But don't water down our message or normalize the Republicans by constantly chasing compromises with the GOP that always turn out badly for us.

Infrastructure is a case in point. Trump's "plan" is simply a corporate tax giveaway to finance toll roads. Democrats must oppose that, and offer actual infrastructure investments instead, rather than trying to tweak Trump's plan to make it slightly less bad. The path to victory is standing up and fighting, not weak compromising.

https://www.facebook.com/WinningProgressive
You misspelled "President".  From now on, it is "president" trump.  (You can capitalize the "T" in trump if you want.  It's optional.)

THe problem is the Dems are always in reactive mode. You say they must come up with economic plans and infrastructure plans. Why didn't they already have them? They just take for granted everyone under 60 and non-white will vote for them so they just don't stand for anything long term.
For the GOP it is pretty simple like it or not. They are for lower taxes, less government regulations, free markets and trickle down econ. Can't say it simply for the Dems.

@Winning Progressive
True, but the fundamental problem is that the Democrats do not represent or care about a populist economic agenda. The vast majority are working on behalf of the corporate donors who funded their campaigns, just like their Republican colleagues.

The most alarming appointment in this brood of billionaires is Betsy Devos. She is a politically partisan Right Wing Conservative,who wants reduce the power of teachers and destroy the political power of teacher's unions. She has no professional educational experience or training, her  attitude toward the LGBT community can only be described as homophobic, she never attended public schools, believes Global Warming is a hoax, and her primary activity has been to lobby for vouchered charter schools, transferring money from financially strapped public schools to religious and private schools. How can anyone with no professional resume, who endorses gender bigotry and anti- science imbecility, be Secretary of Education in a culturally pluralistic society like ours.

@Montreal Moe, Very Interesting comment Moe I lived in East Grand Rapids as a child and went to Lakeside elementary.I think Betsy may really believe in  the concept of the "elect", which when coupled with the nefarious  idea of "predestination", has a self aggrandizing  effect. Her brother after all founded "Blackwater", now Xe.

Perhaps we were lucky, had Liberty University President Jerry Falwell Jr. accepted the job as he says President elect-Donald Trump offered, we might well have been on our way to laying the foundations of a theocracy.
Just think how difficult it is to uproot the Taliban... and when the better half of us are relegated back to the kitchen...

Our Republican governor brought one of those with her. A woman who worked with Jeb Bush in Florida has come to New Mexico to "fix" our "failing schools." Never worked as a teacher, administrator, lunch lady--- anything in any schools, anywhere. But she is in charge. Thank God in New Mexico we have a Democratic legislature that put a check on some of the worst ideas. But still she has the power to change the teacher evaluation system.

In all honesty, it needed some fixing, but by someone who knows about the real job of being a teacher.

I thought your brother's piece was well written. It is simply another point of view. I wish we could start respecting each other's point of view soon. All of this angry Trump bashing and Clinton bashing is tiring. I get it; people do not like Trump. I get it, Hillary lost. People are upset. Tempers are still soaring. But I feel like I am always caught in the crossfire on this. Doesn't anyone else? Meanwhile, what are we teaching our kids about civility? About being good citizens? Are we being good citizens? Seriously, there are people now who do not like one another because one supported Trump and one Hillary. Okay, so, Trump won. Can we stop blaming each other now?

I used to respect the opinions of my fellow commentators for the NYTimes. I loved reading their interesting and well thought out comments. But now I hardly read them anymore. First, they are the same old repeated lines. And there is too much vitriol. It does not flatter any of you, no matter how many recommendations you seek.

You can attack me if you would like, but your comments mean little to me anymore.

This is not about Trump and Hillary anymore. It is now about being mean and nasty. To each other. That is what this election created. Fault whomever you wish, it matters not. What matters is how we treat one another. And most people seem not to care. That is the saddest result of an election I have ever seen.
Yes. As my meditation Master, Baba Muktananda, says, "When your pointing your finger, there are three fingers pointing back at you".

Most people seem not to care that they voted for the man who spent 5 years doing one of the nastiest things ever seen in this country -- telling racists that they were right to hate President Obama because Trump had proof that he was born in Kenya.

Calling out the voters who just enabled that incivility is a necessity if you really believe what you wrote about not being mean and nasty. Otherwise, you are simply saying let's allow people to be as mean and nasty for as long as they want and if they are popular enough to win an election, we should allow them to continue.

Indeed, "what matters is how we treat one another".  I believe that is why trump is detested.  It is one thing to forgive a kind and generous man for being ill-prepared to assume the mantle, but he ran an ugly campaign based almost entirely on gross exaggerations and lies and deliberately designed to tear apart the social fabric.  That is why, IMO, this "is the saddest result of an election".  Some people can say, oh well, he won, it's over, forget the hell of the past year.  I just cannot figure out how they do it.  As you say, this comment will mean little to you but I need to say it and I will keep saying it nonetheless.  Please be assured that my comment is made not for the sake of flattering myself, nor is it made because Ms. Clinton lost, it is made because a mean and vile man won.  It is not something to be proud of: not in my home, not in my neighborhood, not in my country and not in my world.  Not to be forgotten.  Pray never to be seen again.

But the press has grown partisan and given up its contentious and skeptical role a long time ago.Its coverage has also become more trivial too.  Of course the public's distrust of the press has grown accordingly. I'm surprised it is still so high.The disaffection not be solved by fighting a legal change in libel suit rules. This is a very  minor threat. Face the real problems first.

"The closing scenes of his “Silence” follow Rodrigues through the decades after he apostatizes."

Did I really need to know the ending before viewing the film (or reading the book)? I guess I don't have to do either anymore, now that the cat's out of the bag. Thanks for that.

P.S. As gauche as the words "spoiler alert" might seem in a New York Times article, it could help your readers who appreciate the element of surprise.
Surprise? You want a surprise ending in a story that's all about a priest's struggle between faith and actions? Go watch "Transformers" or "Fast and Furious;" might be more entertaining for you.

Perhaps Pope Francis understands that a 2-century-old Church might be using outdated, outmoded, misogynistic moral behavior codes which only diminish the FREE WILL of those it seeks to serve?

Perhaps Pope Francis would rather be a good person and a good pastor, at the expense of being the "good" Pope you and the Dubia seek (that is, "good" in your definition, not in Jesus')?

Perhaps these political games between Apollonians and Dionysians, these swings between freedom and tyranny, are as tiring to him as they are to the entire world?

#WeAreOne
#EmbraceIt

CB, most people blame the President because they don't understand how the government works. The Republicans counted on this when they obstructed President Obama for 8 years. Apparently many voters also have short memories. They have already forgotten how bad things were when President Obama was elected in 2008 and how the economy has improved in the intervening years.

Ms. Dowd, I truly feel for you. May I suggest that you urge your brother, whom I presume lives in very blue New York, to move to one of the deeply red states, where he can have a double dose of GOP utopia.  Kansas Perhaps? Or maybe WV, or Kentucky.  After all, that's where he can watch Trump's promised miracles firsthand.  Why, the locals are sure to welcome him as their liberator, just as the Iraqis did.  And I know Kevin will want to be there for the festivities.

Or come on down to North Carolina where the Republicans have devastated our state financially, educationally, socially and we're all in pain. Thank goidness we elected Roy Cooper to begin to repair the damage, but now we have to deal with all the danage Mr. Trump is going to inflict on our nation as well as the world. You, Mr. Dowd, I'm afraid, will have to eat your words.
My guess is that Kevin Dowd lives in the Northern Virginia suburbs.

Trump is, and always has been, a con man plain and simple. Certainly, his appointment of a bunch of billionaires and millionaires to his cabinet is one sign that his entire "populist" shtick was nothing but a con. But far bigger proof that it was just a con comes from the policies that Trump and the rest of the Republicans are going to be pursuing.

Privatizing Medicare would increase costs and reduce coverage for middle class Americans. It would also enrich a bunch of health insurance companies.

Privatizing Social Security would eviscerate retirement security for tens of millions of Americans, but would be a huge gift to Wall Street.

DeVos' education proposals are all about helping the private sector gain access to all of the money that goes into education.

The GOP's desire to kneecap the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau would put a halt to that bureau's work protecting consumers against corporate and financial fraud, which has already saved consumers $12 billion.

Trump's infrastructure "plan" wouldn't fund any infrastructure projects. Instead, it would provide more than $100 billion in corporate tax giveaways in an effort to encourage privately-funded toll roads and bridges.

None of this should come as a surprise from Trump who spent decades outsourcing jobs, fighting unions, and refusing to pay his contractors. Let's just hope voters realize that they have been conned sooner rather than later.

https://www.facebook.com/WinningProgressive

Aside from nominating De Vos, does anyone actually know for a fact that any of this is going to happen?
Just asking.

@Bryan - we can be pretty certain that the Republicans are going to try to do all those things, because that is exactly what they have said they would do. Paul Ryan has had his knives out for years to eliminate Medicare and leave seniors with inadequate vouchers to try to get insurance from the health insurance industry. Republicans have fought the Consumers Financial Protection Bureau since the day it was created, and Trump said during the campaign that he would eliminate it. And the corporate tax giveaway that pretends to be an infrastructure "plan" is exactly what Trump proposed.

These are all things that we may be able to stop, but only if we organize against the agenda that the Republicans have long said they plan to pursue, and stand in firm opposition to them. We may lose some, or even all, of those fights, but the Democratic position on these issues must be full opposition - no surrender, no retreat.

URSA, OSA and BEAR BRYANT. Good subtheme.

The Highwayman was a poem my father used to read to me. Nice memory.

Always good to see the alma mater in the puzzle.

"This is the forest primeval..."

SO hard to work into conversations!
Phil Ochs set The Highwayman to music and sang it, beautifully.
You-all are kidding, right? The CUBS?

Let me sadly and reluctantly congratulate Kevin Dowd.

Let's hope that Kevin's trust in Trump is not misplaced, although I feel otherwise. Though I'm happy that we'll finally get an infrastructure program, I'm not optimistic about the success of a Trump presidency.

My own focus in the national color war extends to 2018 and 2020. Here's to the Blues retaking additional House and Senate seats in 2018 and capturing the White House in 2020. If my prognostications about a Trump administration are accurate, that shouldn't be too difficult.

But here we had two third party candidates that could be on either side. If you believe that Stein voters would've voted for Clinton, then Johnson voters would've voted for Trump. That ends up being a wash.

The thing is that Clinton should've beaten Trump hands down, even with all her warts. I don't get it. Sexism is part of the answer, but it's not a simple answer. The idea that people think that somehow Trump will fix all the problems with Washington is so illogical to me, I can't get it. But people will know, like they did with Bush 2. Who is proud of their votes for Bush 2?

Personally, I think Gore and Kerry, and now Clinton would've been better than all Bush 2 and Trump. His first term hasn't started yet and I will give it four years before I make a final judgement, but I don't expect it will change. If under Trump, the country improves from where it was as of Dec 31, 2016, then he can claim some of the credit.

Compare where the country was when Bush 2 started to when he left by various metrics. It's going to be worse in 2020 and 2024, if we go that long with a Republican administration. It's not all on the President but in terms of partial credit, the buck stops there.

I don't really care much for the Democrats either, and I agree they have gotten too cozy with the professional and elite classes, but they are better than the Republicans for this country at least as far as this century is concerned.

Frank,
There is nothing pretend about Donald Trump. He is the real deal.
I fear for my wife and children who were taught to love their country. I fear for my grandchildren, we taught them what we believed their country stood for.
I can't talk about my country any more it is rubbing salt in fresh painful wounds.
It is hard to believe things will get any better when the commander in Chief advocates a scorched earth policy.
Winning isn't everything it is only the beginning let us start the humiliation and ridicule. It is time to close some bridges.

I beg to differ with you  about Donald Trump . He is far from being 'blue collar' which is hilarious. The only thing he has worked for is what he has been given.  He spits on the working class people who have voted for him calling them stupid for paying their fair share of taxes.

Really excellent Thai food has been available in several west coast cities for many decades. SF, Seattle and Honolulu is where I started eating Thai food at some of the best restaurants. I was sad when I moved back east and had been served not so good fare over and over. Many people on the east coast had never experienced good Thai so did not know any different, similar to this writer.
You can tell when a restaurant skimps on real ingredients and uses poor quality. Most Thai places are going the way of Chinese, who BTW now own and operate many supposedly Thai restaurants.

‘I ask you what food does Caesar eat that has made him grow so great? Our era should be ashamed! Rome has lost the ability to raise noble men! When was there ever an age, since the beginning of time, that didn’t feature more than one famous man? Until now, no one could say that only one man mattered in all of vast Rome. Now, though, in all of Rome, there’s room for only one man. You and I have heard our fathers talk of another Brutus—your ancestor—who would’ve let the devil himself reign in his Roman Republic before he let a king rule.

“Why, man, he doth bestride the narrow world like a Colossus, and we petty men
walk under his huge legs and peep about
to find ourselves dishonorable graves.”

"The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars, but in ourselves, that we are underlings."

--- Cassius in Shakespeare’s Julius Caesar

I wonder whatever happened to all the Trump signs that the people of ancient Rome had up on their front lawns.
Surely you're not suffering the delusion that his legion gives a whit.

This article is not about HRC.
It's about Trump.
Even if everything you wrote about her is correct how is it relevant
Do not think making her look bad makes Trump look good.
Trump is a joke.
He has no right to be President if he thinks he can be one and still be the head of a international business empire.
He can be one of either but not both..

This extensive account makes plain what many already know: fascism has come to the United States. There will be little accountability if we allow this super-rich autocrat and his billionaire henchmen to plunder the Treasury, privatizing everything, putting public funds at risks for private profit. Not to mention the other issues of having an authoritarian in power.

We do not have to allow it. See you in DC on January 20.

Excuse me, but can you spell Solyndra? How much public funding was lost in that and other solar adventures?
How much private funding will be lost if the Dakota access pipeline, already extensively vetted and licensed, is not allowed to be completed?
I'm sorry, but you have it backwards.

I doubt Trump's supporters read the NYT, but, I agree, if this were broadcast six months ago, maybe the outcome would have been different.  Yet, we had Trump's verbal account of sexual harassment, his racists statement and bold faced lies and, all of that, as shocking as it was, had little influence on his supporters.

Professor Lawrence Lessig, himself a presidential candidate briefly, wrote in the Wash Post that the Electoral College could save the nation by exercising the powers intended for it by the framers of the Constitution, the ability to override the verdict of the states and, in this case, declare the person who got the most votes as president.

Here is a link to that article: http://tinyurl.com/zeljjvd

There was a time when public pressure and media coverage might change the course of history, but we have become so bitterly divided along partisan lines that most of those who supported Trump would automatically reject the facts about his conflicts. There is no mechanism, no safety check, other than the EC and, after that, impeachment proceedings.
comments.userLocation: Beyond the Beltway state of mind

comments.commentBody: Well, guess what, if Trump is inaugurated, your life as an American citizen is over.  Leave him be?  You haven't been reading the news lately.
